abstract: An undirected simple graph G is locally irregular if adjacent vertices of G have different degrees. An edge-colouring ϕ of G is locally irregular if each colour class of ϕ induces a locally irregular subgraph of G. The irregular chromatic index of G is the least number of colours used by a locally irregular edge-colouring of G (if any). We show that the problem of determining the irregular chromatic index of a graph can be handled in linear time when restricted to trees, but it remains NP-complete in general.
